etymology.description: ideogrammic compound: 犬 (dog) + 羊 (sheep); later Qin–Han form with 犬 over 羊; Shuowen also interprets as 屰 (“opposite”) + 夭 (“death”).
etymology.interpretation: Juxtaposing dog and sheep likely evoked auspicious or ritual associations, yielding a sense of propitiousness. The Shuowen reading ‘opposite + death’ conveys averting death—being spared—hence ‘good fortune’ and ‘fortunately’.

examples.chinese: 幸亏你提醒(幸虧你提醒)，我才没迟到(我才沒遲到)。
examples.pinyin: Xìngkuī nǐ tíxǐng, wǒ cái méi chídào.
examples.english: Fortunately you reminded me, so I wasn’t late.

examples.chinese: 祝你们幸福(祝你們幸福)。
